While the safety mechanisms in place on naval vessel nuclear reactors are designed to prevent accidents, like in any system, there still exists the possibility of malfunctions or failures. If the control rods fail or the emergency response plan isn't implemented as expected, an accident could occur.

Fortunately, there has never been a serious nuclear accident on a naval vessel since the first vessel with a nuclear reactor was commissioned in the US navy in 1954. However, there have been some minor incidents, often referred to as "incidents" or "accidents," which have provided lessons in maintaining safety. These incidents were contained, and the safety measures and protocols in place worked as intended to prevent significant harm to the crew or the environment.

However, the safety of naval vessel nuclear reactors is consistently re-evaluated and improved, and there is a continued focus on safety to minimize any potential risk of nuclear incidents. The training of crew and safety measures would prevent accidents on a naval vessel, and the modern designs and safety features ensure that any incident can be minimized.
